Yes, Anabaptist communities have faced a number of challenges in recent years as they try to balance their traditional values with the rapidly changing world around them. Here are a few examples:

1. Technology: As modern technology has advanced, Anabaptist communities have had to grapple with how much to embrace it. Some communities have completely rejected modern technology, while others have found ways to integrate it into their lives in limited ways. However, the rapid pace of technological change can pose a challenge for communities that wish to maintain a more traditional way of life.

2. Generational Differences: As younger members of Anabaptist communities grow up, they may have different attitudes towards traditional values and practices than their parents or grandparents. This can lead to tension and conflict within the community, as younger members may want more independence and modernity while older members wish to maintain their traditional way of life.

3. Financial Pressures: Many Anabaptist communities rely on agriculture or small businesses to support themselves, which can create financial pressures as the cost of living rises and markets become more competitive. Some communities have had to adapt by diversifying their income sources or embracing new business models.

4. Changing Demographics: Anabaptist communities are often located in rural areas, which can pose challenges as younger members may choose to move to urban areas for education or job opportunities. This can lead to a decline in membership and a loss of traditional knowledge and practices.

Overall, Anabaptist communities have faced a number of challenges in balancing their traditional values with the changing times around them. However, by continuing to adapt and innovate, many communities have been able to maintain their core values while also finding new ways to thrive in a rapidly changing world.
